Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: insult and non-insult. Insult is any lanugage or act that is disrespectful or scornfully abusive.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: your posts shows you are stupid period
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is scornful and disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Would you have blamed the Jews for what the Nazis did to them?
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is not an insult because it does not disrespect any group, although the question phrased might be controversial.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Your guy kirk tried to raise gas tax last year! So you agreeing he is a idiot
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a correct answer, because the comment is disrespectful.

Negative Examples.explanation: LOL is an acronym of laugh out loud and is not an insult. This is not a correct answer.
This comment contains explicit targetted language and is considered insult. his is not a correct answer.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Actually it is more likely she would be forced to abort rather than prohibited. The fetus once aborted would be disposed of, but the child would be living proof of the rape.
Negative Examples.explanation: This is an incorrect answer. There is no insult in the given comment.

Comment: This claim should have gone nowhere. Church marriage law presumes that a married couple will have intercourse unless proven otherwise. Then, the burden of proof was on Catherine, and the operative word is "proof". Catherine's unsupported word should not have sufficed, and at the time she made this claim, she was not a virgin. Thus, she had no support whatsoever for her claim. Church marriage law holds that dubious claims about the validity of the marriage are to be dismissed in favor of the validity.

However, her other point of attack depended on her nephew Charles -- King of Spain, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Naples -- to oppose the annulment. Charles disliked Henry both personally and politically, and was happy to help his aunt. 

More importantly, in 1527, Naples and the Papal States had a war, which the Pope lost. Pope Clement VII did not want a re-run of that war, so he stalled by taking Catherine's claim seriously. There were special commissions and so on to waste time.

Read AT's sequence of events - the drunk glared at AT, but after that AT escalated first, at every step of the way. What would have happened if AT had glanced at the man, seen that he was a sitting drunk, and just walked on? Nothing! That's so easy! Maybe the drunk would have cursed or something, so what? Comment: I understand what you're getting at.  The old torts of assault and battery separated the crime into the attempt or threat of using force against a person versus the actual physical force, the battery component.

But it seems pretty clear in Canadian law that determining the actus rea of sexual assault under S271 requires there to be touching, that it was sexual in nature, and that there was no consent.  

It's only under S272 that threatening a sexual assault with a weapon is sufficient to establish the actus rea of sexual assault with a weapon.

Which is why I do believe a verbal threat of sexual touching (without a weapon) would be prosecuted, if at all, as a common assault.

Comment: One would assume that in a legitimately objective legal system the courts (and especially a Supreme Court) must permit input from all relevant stakeholders. By deselecting LGBTQ intervenors in a case where LGBTQ rights and interests are fundamental to the matter at hand, the SCC's original position failed the test of objectivity. Imagine if the SCC were to hear and rule on an appeal application about a pipeline in northern Canada after deselecting intervenors representing aboriginal interests. It just wouldn't happen. And it shouldn't happen, just as it shouldn't in a case where LGBTQ interests as well as the legitimate right of LGBTQ citizens/residents to be protected from discrimination are at stake. This is not about special interests. It's about the right of people from a historically oppressed community to be able to protect themselves from discrimination. To shut them out of the process would have transformed the SCC into little more than a kangaroo court.

Comment: Living in Hawaii Kai and commuting to my job in downtown Honolulu, I used the express bus frequently because I didn't like sitting in traffic, I enjoyed having more discretionary income by not paying for parking, fuel, and higher insurance premiums, and the short walks to and from the bus stops gave me greater appreciation of the neighborhood.  A few years ago, I rode the Washington DC Metro for the first time and I said, "Wow!"  I kept thinking how wonderful it would have been if we had something like that for my Hawaii Kai commute.  I wish everyone could experience these metro systems.  They are clean, on time, safe, comfortable, and reasonably priced and quiet.  Much of the DC metro is underground, but the Oahu Rail will be above ground, so yes, you will have your quiet moments to reflect on part of the island and neighborhoods.  I call these "mind yawns."  We all need them.

Comment: The best discussions of white privilege are held in the context of a discussion of all the various kinds of privilege. It is well worth discussing the way some powerful psycho-social forces take the form of white privilege. The privilege of being able to escape certain kinds of suffering is a very important privilege to include here. 

But the racializing of the idea of privilege is fraught with distortions, since race itself is a treacherous and ungrounded concept. Some “white” privilege has just been the privilege of being in the majority. All majorities have privileges--in markets and democracies and elsewhere. The downside of the re-racializing of America (by intellectuals) as a means to achieve racial justice is that it reinforces the concept of race as something more than just a tool to expose racism. 

And teachers unfortunately (often through transference) tend to produce white guilt in children who will reject that guilt--and often the whole idea of privilege. Dangerous!

Comment: And once again we run into the problem of translating meaning-laden Greek and Latin into simplistic English.

The Koine word being translated as “divorce”, “adultery”, and so on in various translations is “porneia”. A direct translation is usually “sexual immorality” but its import is much more than that. A better phrasing might be “sexual depravity”.

It includes adultery, fornication, prostitution, homosexual relations, incest, group activities, and so on. It is a very negative word. One would not use it for the average adulterer.

What it is describing is someone who is incapable of contracting a marriage because they cannot be monogamous.

Today that would be grounds for annulment because the party could not contract a marriage.

Expecting such individuals to identify their background is not it's not desirable. Clearly if their opinions are flattering to those in power, identity would not be a problem, but criticism would be. Comment: One can take the Church too seriously (horrors) and overlook the sins of the institution as if they didn't matter because the official teaching of the Church says otherwise. One finds this disingenuous. The Church teaches by example and if her example is so fraught with error one may look askance at claims that her teaching authority, be it honorable, is in any way infallible. 
     For example: if life is sacred from conception to natural death, what of the Buddhists killed by Diem, a professed Catholic in Vietnam, whose oppressive actions led to the self-immolation of Buddhist monks? Comment: The primary definition of a “weapon” is: “a thing designed or used for inflicting bodily harm or physical damage.”
A "lash" is the flexible part of a whip. A whip is primarily used to cause pain as punishment or as a stimulus to action. I suspect that Jesus wasn't intent on inflicting bodily harm on the moneychangers, and upsetting the tables may have scattered "the merchandise," but there was no physical damage.
Jesus "took the lash" to "stimulate" an examination of conscience: "It is written: 'My house shall be a house of prayer,' but you are making it a den of thieves.'" (Mt. 21:13)
Again, the one time a weapon -- a sword not a whip -- was wielded in Jesus’ presence, he clearly demanded, “Stop, no more of this!” (Lk.21:51)
Jesus "took the lash" once and then laid it down. He said, "I have given you a model to follow." We have taken and continue taking up arms to inflict bodily pain and physical damage. When will we follow Jesus example and lay down all weapons?

Hillary Clinton is carrying out the work of Satan and Catholics who vote Democrat are going to hell. That’s the message of a recent bulletin at a San Diego Catholic church.  
“It is a mortal sin to vote Democrat,” a flyer distributed at the Immaculate Conception Catholic Church in Old Town read, according to the San Diego Union-Tribune. “Immediately after death the souls of those who die in a state of mortal sin descend into hell.”
The Oct. 16 flyer, called “Voters Guide for Serious Catholics,” was written in English and Spanish and tucked into the weekly bulletin given out at the church, which also serves as a polling place.

Comment: Part 1
There are many reasons why the medieval development of the altar as wall with a tabernacle as its center piece was not fortuitous. 

The most important has to do with our conception of the Eucharist as PRIMARILY (1) sacred food and drink, or (2) an object of adoration. 

The essence of Eucharist in scripture is sacred food. Jesus confected the Eurcharist at the Last Supper at the dinner table, and commanded us to both eat and drink. For most of the first thousand years, our churches faithfully conveyed that original divine intent with an altar that was instantly recognizable as a dinner table, to which bread and wine were brought, and from with the body and blood of Christ was distributed as sacred food and drink in the form of bread and wine. The original scriptural word that was adopted for a church building was "ekklesia," which means "gathering" and which came to be understood as the "place of gathering." Its Jewish predecessor was the synagogue (essentially same meaning).

Comment: LOTL, that petition you mention in your last sentence can be read in John's Gospel  (17:21). Since you made the sentence an exclamation, I presume that you, like me, recognize just how pivotal is the petition to (and how definitional of) any genuine claim to be Jesus' disciple. What exactly was Jesus asking of his Father? If you read to the end of the chapter, the answer is clearly stated: "...that the love with which thou hast loved me may be in them, and I in them." (The New Oxford Annotated Bible, v 26)

The unity Jesus seeks of his followers is primarily a unity in love, not doctrine. I don't deny the importance of doctrine, but I do deny that it has supreme importance. Belief in (intellectual assent to) the dogma of the Eucharist cannot redeem a person: only Eucharistic love, manifested in and through word and deed, can do this. Note, however, that intellectual assent to Eucharistic dogma is not a condition for exercising the love referenced by the dogma.

Comment: The pontifical secret applies to “extrajudicial denunciations”, an allegation of child sexual abuse made to the superior of the accused. It does not apply where a curate is told about the abuse of his parish priest, but vice versa it does. It does not apply where a bishop walks into a priest’s bedroom and finds him abusing a child. His knowledge come from his own eyes and not from any extrajudicial denunciation or any inquiry that he might set up. But these are unusual circumstances. Most of the bishops’ knowledge comes from someone complaining to him about the abuse by a priest under his control, and those allegations are covered by the secret. Those who accidentally come across this information are also bound by the secret. Francis knows about the secret because the Argentinian protocol which was two years in the drafting, was signed off by his fellow bishops one month after he became pope. Art 17 states “as a first warning” that these cases are subject to the pontifical secret.

Comment: What's right about this editorial?  Most cops are good people and deserve honor and respect.  What's wrong with this article?  It misses the point of current policing problems.  We employ police.  We tell them the tactics to use.  We have told them through representatives to be militaristic, to acquire advanced weaponry, to confront citizens and demand instant submission on pain of death.

To solve the problem we need to step back and reflect on how we want police to operate.  Currently, police confront aggressively and thus place themselves in harm's way.  Consequently, police shoot to kill to protect themselves at the first, often misinterpreted, sign of threat.  Once in a while aggressive approach is necessary.  Usually, the matter in question is not so important and it would be better to let the perp go rather than to kill him.   With this change in attitude, police need not recklessly enter into harm's way and shoot to kill without observation, evaluation, and reflection.

Comment: In the 2008 movie "Recount" Tom Wilkerson played James Baker, lead counsel for the Bush team in "Bush v. Gore." In the movie, and I can only assume this is based on fact, Baker tells his legal team, "this is a street fight, boys," while Gore's legal team was playing by strict Marquess of Queensberry rules. Gore lost and the street fighters won. So it has been ever since. 

Whenever Republicans can find a loophole to circumvent the law, procedure, precedent, whatever it takes to win, they take it, and the people who vote for them register their approval by reelecting them. That means that if our democracy is being whittled away by the present Republican-controlled Congress it is because their constituents in their gerrymandered districts have allowed it. Something tells me that when the full implications of their actions dawn on them down the line they'll regret having supported people who violated two centuries of convention for short-term political gain. By then it will be too late.

In this case both the Crown and defense counsel agreed Li met the definition of NCRMD (as did all the psychiatric experts) and made joint submission to the trial judge.

It is a fundamental principle of criminal law that one must have the requisite 'mens rea' to commit a crime... any crime and in Li's case this was absent.  This principle dates back many centuries in English law and we have passed a version of the  M'Naghten Rule into our Criminal Code when it was first drafted.  Queen v. M'Naghten, 8 Eng. Rep. 718 [1843]

We do not punish persons who are found NCRMD.

Comment: No, I am really not. Philosophy - from the Greek "philos' meaning love and "sophos" meaning "Wisdom", the love of wisdom - is literally the study of how to think straight.

If you haven't learned philosophy, you will never be able to form a logical thought. No, what people think they are doing isn't logic. Logic is a set of rules. To think logically you have to know those rules, and apply those rules (much like algebra is a set of rules you have to know and apply to get the right answer).

To think you can be logical without studying philosophy is like claiming you can do algebra without learning to count first. 

Here's how it works:
Philosophers figure out how to understand things.
Scientists use those techniques to understand a particular thing.
Engineers use that understanding to solve practical problems.

Unfortunately - because true logic is so often counter-intuitive, those not schooled in it tend to think actual logical arguments are "stupid" because their intuition says so.

Is being gay or straight  like being left handed or right handed?  Is life in a mother's womb a human life or is it not?  What constitutes "free speech"? " What are the limits of free speech? Comment: Yes.  If we are talking about actual sexual assault survivors, i.e. the victim of a violent sexual assault, then I agree with him.  However if we are embracing the hysterics of 'all women must be believed, then I take issue.  I have investigated both, and done a proper job on each one.   The difference is that when it is obvious that the complainant is not truthful, it is maddening.  Time and resources are wasted.   Please note, I am not saying kick them out the door in the first instance.   However, when you have spoken to the complainant, then the suspect, and any witnesses involved, and there is no evidence, it is time to go.  This is where the unfounded come in.   Once the matter is headed for the courts, I fully support the complainant, because there is evidence to support the allegations. Prior to that, it is the job of the police to ask probing questions, especially if we feel we are being lied to and manipulated.

Comment: Animals are not people. A hunter is not convicted of murder, if he shoots a deer. An unwanted animal often suffers if it is allowed to live, even if healthy. A cat once came to my country home in a state of starvation. I managed to feed it and save its life. However, I have also had a female cat that kept producing more and more batches of kittens. It was impossible to provide for them all. I placed the unwanted kittens in a gunny sack containing a stone, tied up the sack, and placed it in a pond so that the kittens would drown. It was a painless death. In another case, to avoid offspring, I shot and killed our mother cat. Often such methods prevent unnecessary suffering of animals. I also shoot and kill porcupines whenever I can. When our dogs go after them, the porcupines slap their tails at the dogs, and the dogs come home with hurtful quills. When we pull out these quills, the dogs suffer considerable pain. Mercy killing is often the best solution to save animals from pain.

Comment: There are several problems with "natural law". There are multiple definitions of the term. One is "the law written in human hearts" (see Aquinas' Summa Theologica, I-II, q 94, art 6.) Another is "what is found in nature". (There is a third, having to do with legal theories.)

In practice, "natural law" can be misused in several ways:

It can mean nothing more than "this is what is written in my heart", which is the same as "in my opinion". Personal opinion is not a good basis for moral or dogmatic teachings.

It can be invoked when the person does not have an actual argument. A good example is in Humanae Vitae 4, which says essentially "we know the natural law, and you will just have to take our word for it". That's not an argument, that's blather.

When it does not actually describe how nature works. Humanae Vitae says that in nature, sexual intercourse is used for procreation. In fact, many of the great apes use it for pair bonding. So the author of HV got it wrong.

Comment: Fr. Reese, I think your insights here are helpful & show your openness to understanding the the Scriptures based on a critical, studious analysis, which I'm sure your theology study has taught you to do. I find this the most insightful way to read the Scriptures - in a studious, intellectually humble manner. 

And yet I wanted to add (& you may be aware of this argument) that the word that the translation that you provided renders as "unlawful marriage" may better be translated as "adultery". I understand that the Koine Greek word "porneia" is debated, but I read an intriguing argument for its being translated as "adultery" - in the sense of secretive sexual intercourse with a man other than the woman's husband - as the more accurate term. This is based on the fact that in the Septuagint translation, the word "porneia" is often used in a phrase alongside another Greek word, "moixeia", to translate OT Hebrew phrases in which both words, in each context, refer to such manner of adultery.

Comment: Perhaps the biggest problem with the American version of democracy is that it doesn't apportion power to the people in direct proportion to the vote.  Votes would mean more if they translated into proportional representation.   39% vote for Party X ... 39% of seats in government go to Party X.   Instead of a winner-take-all approach, which, as you say, can result in all the power given to the most populous states, it would mean more to make sure every political party that represents us finds a seat at the table.  One of the biggest mistakes our Founding Fathers made was to reject a parliamentary form of government.  In their rush to declare independence, they experimented with a different kind of democracy.  Not sure how the next four years will go, of course, but let's see how Republicans run the country as a minority.

If the salesperson felt unable to to reach the assigned target, then "no" would have been the right answer -- not "force-selling" or (worse still) raising credit limits or moving customers to pricier accounts on the sly. These are the illegal actions of individual employees.  I doubt very much that TD promotes and condones institutionalized fraud. 

Customers are responsible for consent too. Rather than being passively conned and sheared like sheep, the simple word "no" works wonders. Do try it.

Comment: MC, First, this site purports to use some mix of "NEA, job survey and private data" to come up with their numbers. In their own words, it's "tricky business". Second, the numbers aren't actual salaries, but are a "comfort index" which tries to give a weighted metric vis a vis cost of living(which can vary a lot within states). Hardly "hard data" to make a policy decision off of, but perhaps useful for rookie teachers looking for work, maybe.  Just having starting and average salaries doesn't tell you the whole story. Averages can be skewed by very  high/low earners, a more useful number is median salary. And again, it doesn't address the total compensation issue, or any other factors that are involved that make one state's situation different from anothers. Still waiting for that comprehensive study to be dug up. I think I'll be waiting a while.

Comment: Those of us facing this law and similar ones across the country must not stand by and let campus carry become our new reality. If we accept armed campuses as inevitable, then we are adapting our way toward the demise of the public university in America. We already endure funding cuts, crumbling infrastructure, the adjunctification of teaching, assaults on academic freedom and now … assault rifles in our classrooms? If we accept this latest legislative attack, we risk becoming the proverbial frog who is slowly boiled alive. Although recent experiments refute the scientific veracity of this tale, it is nonetheless an apt metaphor for where the modern public institution finds itself -- in hot water that’s getting hotter. Guns on campuses make the vulnerable even more vulnerable, argues Philip Nel. They uphold established systems of power: white supremacy, patriarchy and the privilege of the tenured.

Comment: The lower dam was apparently plugged by rafting up logs then submerging them by piling rock on them, to form a latticework plug, of sorts, so why not just dredge them out and let the river flow under the dam, then install a gate to store water for times of drought? The upper dam could have been similarly drilled under to allowed the lakes to refill in flood season, protecting downstream property and then used as a reservoir in Summer. We spent millions of scarce tax dollars for the aesthetics of a "wild" canyon for a few tourists. Once the lakes were drained the dams could collapse in an earthquake with no real harm done, but would likely stand if a seismic sensor automatically opened the drains if things started rocking. Now we have to spend millions more each year repairing flood damage and building new reservoirs, which will likely have their own hazards, and the animals and birds that had come to rely on those lakes for habitat had to move on or die. Idiots R Us. Your tax $ @ jerk.

Comment: How much further down this road of politicians virtue signaling around sexual assault are we going to go?

We're already treating sexual assault to completely different standards than we do other violent crimes. Crown witnesses in sexual assault cases are presumed victims in most of the language, can give court testimony remotely so they don't have to face the accused directly, and are guaranteed anonymity that other Crown witnesses do not get.  Now we're talking specialized training on the federal dollar for sensitivity, but just for that one offense?

Are we going to stop before evidentiary standards get watered down, or before 'innocent until proven guilty' becomes a thing of the past ... just for this offense?  I'm reminded of the UCR, which leads off their section on violent crime by noting men and women see roughly equal violent crime rates ... and then follows that up with a section devoted to arguing how women still have it worse, despite the equal rates.

Comment: "If the gassing of the population didn't have any dramatic effect..."  This precisely the point.  The dramatic effect produced was an attack by Trump on Syrian government forces.  The Syrian government had reasons not to use CW rather than to use them.  If an entire rebel held town had been wiped out, one might concede that government forces would do it to avoid street-to-street fighting, i.e. a military benefit that would save some of its soldier's lives.  That is not what happened.  A small number (in the overall context) of people were apparently killed by chemicals.  Use of CW to cause this small pocket of deaths provided negligible military advantage but did provide dramatic effect, a high probability dramatic effect, of opening direct conflict between the Syrian government and the US.  In the end, Assad cannot survive US involvement; therefore, out of his self interest, he would not use CW.  The rebels win big through their use.

Comment: "...“We can say to the alt-right and the neo-Nazis and the KKK: Get over it, you’re African, OK?”..."

Genetically she's correct, but practically she's not.  Read a really good book about two decades ago where the author tried to explain why there are cultural differences between our races.  He basically boiled it down to location.  Races that lived in the more moderate or tropical climates had many means of accessing food and the challenges by the weather for shelter was minimal.  The necessity for technology was minimized.  Cultures in climates farther away from the equator had to not only fight for resource but also develop technologies to advance in the harsher conditions.  Seemed pretty interesting.  It certainly doesn't mean someone from an equatorial climate couldn't successfully enter the more technological environment.  But, there isn't as much necessity for it.

Trump's an idiot in many ways, with or without racist behavior.

Comment: "Denver needs better mobility so that people don’t leave the city faster than they came..."

Then stop taking away car lanes for bike lanes that see 1/1,000th of the human traffic volume. Growing up on the east coast where congestion/density is the norm, watching the missteps of Denver's travel infrastructure over the last 20 years has been infuriating. And the fact that the City traffic planners/engineers still don't comprehend the concept of a "thoroughfare" is absolutely mind boggling. [yes - that's right - making side streets wait 4 minutes for a mass volume of traffic to pass can be the necessary/more-efficient approach]

It's 2017 - there are plenty of example cities to draw from to solve our mobility woes - get it together, Denver. You've spent billions on I-25 expansion, light rail lines, heavy rail lines, bike lanes, pedestrian paths, busses, etc. and you have nothing to show for it. It's pathetic and embarrassing. You all (city planners) should be ashamed of yourselves.

Comment: You want proof? I switched to being a private investor this year. Started selling my funds at the end of January: put more than 1/2 the money in high interest savings and term deposits and invested the rest in equities, starting in May. I had absolutely no experience when I started. Just did a whole lot of reading and talked to people who've been investing for years. Invested mainly in blue chips. For fun, I check the performance of my old funds on a daily basis. Here's where things stand today, 4 months after taking the plunge: 1) my old TFSA fund, 1.33% YTD; my new TFSA, 6.51%; 2) my old RRSP fund, 0.76 % YTD; I have two new RRSPs: one in a savings account at @ 2.10%, the other invested in the market is at 3.21%: the plan is to invest more in equities as I gain more experience; 3) my old RRIF fund is at minus 0.30% YTD; my new RRIF is earning 2.40%. So, in four months, and with no experience, my investments are doing better than with an advisor. Draw your own conclusions...
